caption: The Great Sioux Reservation established by the Treaty of 1851 was supposed to reserve millions of acres for the exclusive use of the Lakota/Dakota peoples forever.
Boundaries were quickly shrunk in the Treaty of 1868 as settlers and developers pressed into Lakota/Dakota territory.
When the Lakota/Dakota people would not agree to a new treaty, Congress stole additional land, including the gold-filled Black Hills.
Lakota/Dakota lands were fractured and dispersed into smaller chunks, as development pressure by non-Indians continued.
The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers' Oahe Dam on the Missouri River in 1958 flooded much of the last best agricultural lands the Lakota/Dakota had.
Today the Lakota/Dakota people's reservation is reduced to just fragments of their ancestral lands.
